articles.title: 3,000 years of secrets hidden beneath Egypt’s greatest temple
articles.summary: A sweeping new geoarchaeological study has revealed how Egypt’s famed Karnak Temple complex rose from an island amid Nile floods to become one of the ancient world’s most enduring sacred centers. By analyzing sediments and pottery fragments, researchers traced its transformation across three millennia and uncovered evidence that its placement may have mirrored the ancient Egyptian creation myth—where the first land emerged from primeval waters.
articles.content:
Most complete study of the temple complex and its landscape establishes earliest occupation and hints at link to creation myth.

Researchers have carried out the most comprehensive geoarcheological survey of Egypt's Karnak Temple near Luxor - one of the ancient world's largest temple complexes and a UNESCO World Heritage site welcoming millions of tourists every year.

The study, published in Antiquity today (October 6) reveals new evidence on the age of the temple, tantalising links to ancient Egyptian mythology, and new insights about the interplay between the temple's riverine landscape and the people who occupied and developed the site over its 3,000 years of use.

"This new research provides unprecedented detail on the evolution of Karnak Temple, from a small island to one of the defining institutions of Ancient Egypt," says Dr Ben Pennington, lead author of the paper and a Visiting Fellow in Geoarchaeology at the University of Southampton.

Karnak temple is located 500 meters east of the present-day River Nile near Luxor, at the Ancient Egyptian religious capital of Thebes.

An international research team, led by Dr Angus Graham (Uppsala University) and involving several academics from the University of Southampton, analyzed 61 sediment cores from within and around the temple site. The team also studied tens of thousands of ceramic fragments to help date their findings.

Using this evidence, researchers have been able to map out how the landscape around the site changed throughout its history.

They found that prior to about 2520 BCE, the site would have been unsuitable for permanent occupation due to being regularly flooded by fast-flowing water from the Nile. This means the earliest occupation at Karnak would have likely been during the Old Kingdom (c.2591-2152 BC). Ceramic fragments found at the site corroborate this finding, with the earliest dating from sometime between c.2305 to 1980 BC.

Dr Kristian Strutt, a co-author of the paper from the University of Southampton, said: "The age of Karnak Temple has been hotly contested in archaeological circles, but our new evidence places a temporal constraint on its earliest occupation and construction."

The land on which Karnak was founded was formed when river channels cut into their beds to the west and east, creating an island of high ground in what is now the east/south-east of the temple precinct. This emerging island provided the foundation for occupation and early construction of Karnak temple.

Over subsequent centuries and millennia, the river channels either side of the site diverged further, creating more space for the temple complex to develop.

Researchers were surprised to find that the eastern channel - until this study not much more than a supposition - was more well-defined, and perhaps even larger than the channel to the west, which archeologists had previously focused on.

Dominic Barker, another co-author also from the University of Southampton added: "The river channels surrounding the site shaped how the temple could develop and where, with new construction taking place on top of old rivers as they silted up."

"We also see how Ancient Egyptians shaped the river itself, through the dumping of sands from the desert into channels, possibly to provide new land for building, for example."

This new understanding of the temple's landscape has striking similarities to an Ancient Egyptian creation myth, leading the team to believe that the decision to locate the temple here could have been linked to the religious views of its inhabitants.

Ancient Egyptian texts of the Old Kingdom say that the creator god manifested as high ground, emerging from 'the lake'. The island upon which Karnak was found is the only known such area of high ground surrounded by water in the area.

"It's tempting to suggest the Theban elites chose Karnak's location for the dwelling place of a new form of the creator god, 'Ra-Amun', as it fitted the cosmogonical scene of high ground emerging from surrounding water," says Dr Pennington.

"Later texts of the Middle Kingdom (c.1980-1760 BC) develop this idea, with the 'primeval mound' rising from the 'Waters of Chaos'. During this period, the abating of the annual flood would have echoed this scene, with the mound on which Karnak was built appearing to 'rise' and grow from the receding floodwaters."

With a concession to study the whole floodplain of the Luxor region, the team are now planning and carrying out work at other major sites in the area, to further understand the landscapes and waterscapes of the whole Ancient Egyptian religious capital zone.

The Conceptual origins and geomorphic evolution of the temple of Amun-Ra at Karnak (Luxor, Egypt) is published in Antiquity and is available online.

The work was supported by the Knut och Alice Wallenbergs Stiftelse (KAW 2013.0163) and Uppsala Universitet (HUMSAM 2014/17), together with a small grant from M och S Wångstedts Stiftelse. The work was carried out under the auspices of the Egypt Exploration Society (London) with a permit from the Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities (Egypt).
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant archaeological and geoarchaeological breakthrough that sheds new light on the history and cultural significance of Egypt's Karnak Temple, a major world heritage site. This discovery has broad cultural and historical importance, enriching our understanding of ancient civilizations and their relationship with the environment. The study is detailed and focused, revealing new insights with potential to inspire curiosity and appreciation for human heritage globally.
articles.personality_title: New study reveals how Karnak Temple rose from Nile floods over 3,000 years ago
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Karnak Temple near Luxor, Egypt, is one of the largest ancient temple complexes in the world. It has been an important religious site for thousands of years but the details about its earliest beginnings and its connection to the landscape were not fully understood.

**What happened** – Researchers from several universities studied sediments and pottery pieces at Karnak to learn how the temple’s site changed over 3,000 years. They found that before about 2520 BCE, the area was regularly flooded by the Nile River, making it hard to live there. Over time, river channels carved out an island of high land where the temple was built. This island became the foundation for Karnak’s growth. The team also discovered that the temple’s location may have been chosen because it matched an ancient Egyptian creation story about land rising from water.

**Impact** – This is the most detailed study of Karnak’s landscape and history so far. It shows how the temple’s builders worked with the changing river to create a lasting sacred place. The findings connect the temple’s location to Egyptian religious beliefs about the world’s beginnings, providing new understanding of how ancient people related to their environment and faith.

**What's next step** – The research team plans to study other important sites in the Luxor region to learn more about the ancient religious capital’s landscape and how water shaped the area’s history. Their work will continue to reveal how ancient Egyptians lived and built their sacred places.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New research shows Karnak Temple grew from a Nile island shaped by floods, linking its location to ancient Egyptian creation myths and revealing 3,000 years of history beneath the sacred site.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle étude révèle comment le temple de Karnak a émergé des inondations du Nil il y a 3 000 ans
articles.personality_presentation_fr:

articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo estudio revela cómo el templo de Karnak surgió de las inundaciones del Nilo hace 3.000 años
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El templo de Karnak cerca de Luxor, Egipto, es uno de los complejos de templos antiguos más grandes del mundo. Ha sido un lugar religioso importante durante miles de años, pero no se entendían bien sus comienzos ni su relación con el paisaje.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de varias universidades estudiaron sedimentos y fragmentos de cerámica en Karnak para descubrir cómo cambió el sitio del templo durante 3.000 años. Encontraron que antes de aproximadamente 2520 a.C., el área se inundaba con frecuencia por el río Nilo, dificultando la vida. Con el tiempo, los canales del río formaron una isla de tierra alta donde se construyó el templo. Esta isla fue la base para el crecimiento de Karnak. También descubrieron que la ubicación del templo pudo haberse elegido porque coincidía con un antiguo mito egipcio de la creación, donde la tierra surge del agua.

**Impacto** – Este es el estudio más detallado realizado hasta ahora sobre el paisaje e historia de Karnak. Muestra cómo los constructores del templo trabajaron con el río cambiante para crear un lugar sagrado duradero. Los hallazgos conectan la ubicación del templo con las creencias religiosas egipcias sobre los orígenes del mundo, dando nueva comprensión de cómo los antiguos egipcios se relacionaban con su entorno y su fe.

**Próximo paso** – El equipo planea estudiar otros sitios importantes en la región de Luxor para aprender más sobre el paisaje de la antigua capital religiosa y cómo el agua moldeó su historia. Su trabajo seguirá revelando cómo vivían y construían sus lugares sagrados los antiguos egipcios.

**Resumen en una frase** – Una nueva investigación muestra que el templo de Karnak creció en una isla del Nilo formada por inundaciones, vinculando su ubicación con mitos egipcios de creación y revelando 3.000 años de historia bajo este sitio sagrado.

articles.title: For 170 years, U.S. Cities have followed a hidden law of growth and decline
articles.summary: Despite massive technological and industrial changes, American cities have stayed remarkably coherent in how their economies fit together. This hidden order governs how cities diversify, grow, and reinvent themselves without losing their economic identity.
articles.content:
A new study out of the Complexity Science Hub (CSH) reveals that, over 170 years of economic history, the transformation of U.S. cities follows a surprisingly stable rule: while cities evolve and diversify, they on average maintain a constant level of "coherence" -- a measure of how well their economic activities fit together.

The research by Simone Daniotti, Matte Hartog, and Frank Neffke analyzed a unique dataset of 650 million U.S. census records, 6 million patents, and other historical sources covering nearly two centuries of urban development.

"We observed that, on average, the cities that make up the U.S urban system transform gradually but surely over time-from craftsmanship and manufacturing to services and engineering. Despite this, they maintain a constant level of coherence for nearly two centuries," explains CSH fellow Daniotti, first author of the study.

West Coast: rapid diversification, constant coherence

"This also happened and in the same way on the West Coast, which developed later and initially in isolation from the wider U.S.. In 1850, cities such as Los Angeles and San Francisco are just emerging there with the onset of the Gold Rush," adds Daniotti, who is also a researcher at Utrecht University.

The study reveals that the West Coast experienced a rapid and far-reaching structural shift. "The transformation was massive-faster and more pronounced than on the East Coast," says Daniotti. In 1850, less than half of all the export-oriented occupations that existed in the wider US were also practiced on the West Coast -- but within just fifty years, that share had surged to nearly 90%. "But, despite rapid diversification, West Coast cities' average coherence remained remarkable constant and at levels that were comparable to those of eastern US cities."

Why transformations are constrained

"The findings show that, although cities develop new activities and abandon old ones, they do so in a way that keeps their coherence constant. This suggests that such transformations are constrained: although cities can develop new activities and drop old ones, while doing so, the set of industries they maintain seems to need to stay coherent at any given point in time," explains Neffke, who leads CSH's Transforming Economies research group.

"So even in cases like Pittsburgh or Boston, which went through periods of prolonged decline and only emerged from those after abandoning their heavy manufacturing industries in steel and manufacturing for high-tech production and services, they needed to find a path that would allow them to do so without jeopardizing their coherence," adds Neffke.

Size matters: coherence shrinks as cities grow

In addition, the study shows that larger cities are consistently less coherent, with coherence declining at a stable rate of about 4% for each doubling of population size. Even though technologies have changed dramatically -- from railroads and telephones to mass production, computers, and AI -- and the U.S. population has grown from about 23 million in 1850 to 332 million in 2022 while moving steadily westward, the way coherence scales with population size has stayed the same.

"This suggests that the way economic activity is distributed within an urban system follows some universal regularities that constrain the amount of diversity that cities can maintain -- keeping them coherent -- based on the size of their population," says Neffke.

Policy lessons: balancing diversification and coherence

A number of lessons can be learned from these findings by policymakers, according to the researchers. While the drive to branch out into emerging technologies is understandable, cities cannot spread themselves too thin -- they must maintain a degree of coherence. "The reason is that the capability base that supports their existing economic structure and is embedded in local infrastructure, workforce, and institutions is expensive to maintain and therefore is ideally kept compact," explains Neffke.

"However, larger cities can sustain a broader set of capabilities, which gives them more room for diversification. But the amount of diversity a city can realistically support is tied to its size. This highlights the importance of benchmarking cities against peers of similar sizes and to recognize that ambitions for diversification are ultimately constrained by size."

What Coherence Means for Cities

In the study, coherence is the glue that holds a city's economy together. It reflects how similar or connected two randomly chosen workers -- or firms, or patents -- in the same city are in terms of their occupations, industries, or technologies.

To explain this in simple terms, coherence combines three related ideas, according to Daniotti. First, the variety of activities a city hosts; second, the balance of how evenly these activities are spread across the workforce; and third, the disparity in how different those activities are from each other.

A highly coherent city tends to have fewer industries that are closely related, like Detroit during its golden age of car-making, while a less coherent city, such as New York City, may span many unrelated sectors.
articles.reasoning: The article presents a significant scientific study revealing a stable economic pattern in U.S. cities over 170 years, offering valuable insights for urban policy and economic development. It has broad societal relevance by informing how cities can balance diversification and coherence to sustain growth and transformation. The study is detailed, based on extensive historical data, and provides actionable lessons for policymakers, thus meeting the criteria for inspiring good news.
articles.personality_title: Study finds U.S. cities follow a steady economic pattern for 170 years
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Over the past 170 years, American cities have changed a lot with new industries and technologies. Yet, a new study shows their economies have kept a steady balance in how different jobs and businesses fit together.

**What happened** – Researchers from the Complexity Science Hub analyzed 650 million census records and millions of patents from nearly two centuries. They discovered that while cities grow and shift from manufacturing to services or tech, they maintain a constant level of "coherence." This means their economic activities stay connected and balanced, even as the types of jobs change.

**Impact** – This finding is important because it shows cities don’t just grow randomly. Instead, they follow a hidden rule that keeps their economy organized. For example, West Coast cities like Los Angeles and San Francisco quickly caught up with older cities but kept the same balance. Also, bigger cities tend to have more variety but slightly less coherence, meaning they spread out into more different industries.

**What's next step** – Policymakers can use this knowledge to help cities grow in smart ways. Cities should try to develop new industries but keep them related enough to stay balanced. This helps avoid spreading resources too thin and supports steady economic health. Cities can also compare themselves to others of similar size to set realistic goals.

**One-sentence takeaway** – For nearly two centuries, U.S. cities have grown and changed economically by following a steady pattern that keeps their industries connected and balanced.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une étude révèle un modèle économique stable dans les villes américaines depuis 170 ans
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Au cours des 170 dernières années, les villes américaines ont beaucoup évolué avec de nouvelles industries et technologies. Pourtant, une nouvelle étude montre que leurs économies gardent un équilibre constant dans la façon dont les différents emplois et entreprises s’articulent.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs du Complexity Science Hub ont analysé 650 millions de données de recensement et des millions de brevets sur près de deux siècles. Ils ont découvert que, même si les villes passent de la fabrication aux services ou à la technologie, elles maintiennent un niveau constant de « cohérence ». Cela signifie que leurs activités économiques restent liées et équilibrées, même si les types d’emplois changent.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle montre que la croissance des villes n’est pas aléatoire. Elles suivent une règle cachée qui organise leur économie. Par exemple, les villes de la côte Ouest comme Los Angeles et San Francisco ont rapidement rattrapé les villes plus anciennes tout en gardant ce même équilibre. De plus, les grandes villes ont plus de diversité mais une cohérence un peu moindre, ce qui signifie qu’elles s’étendent dans plus d’industries différentes.

**Prochaine étape** – Les décideurs peuvent utiliser ces connaissances pour aider les villes à se développer intelligemment. Les villes doivent essayer de créer de nouvelles industries tout en les gardant liées pour rester équilibrées. Cela évite de disperser les ressources et soutient une santé économique stable. Les villes peuvent aussi se comparer à d’autres de taille similaire pour fixer des objectifs réalistes.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Depuis près de deux siècles, les villes américaines se développent économiquement en suivant un modèle stable qui maintient leurs industries connectées et équilibrées.
articles.personality_title_es: Un estudio descubre un patrón económico estable en las ciudades de EE.UU. durante 170 años
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante los últimos 170 años, las ciudades estadounidenses han cambiado mucho con nuevas industrias y tecnologías. Sin embargo, un nuevo estudio muestra que sus economías mantienen un equilibrio constante en cómo se relacionan los diferentes trabajos y negocios.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores del Complexity Science Hub analizaron 650 millones de registros del censo y millones de patentes de casi dos siglos. Descubrieron que, aunque las ciudades crecen y cambian de manufactura a servicios o tecnología, mantienen un nivel constante de "coherencia". Esto significa que sus actividades económicas permanecen conectadas y equilibradas, incluso cuando cambian los tipos de empleos.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo es importante porque muestra que las ciudades no crecen de manera aleatoria. Siguen una regla oculta que mantiene su economía organizada. Por ejemplo, ciudades de la costa oeste como Los Ángeles y San Francisco alcanzaron rápido a las ciudades más antiguas pero mantuvieron el mismo equilibrio. Además, las ciudades más grandes tienden a tener más variedad pero un poco menos de coherencia, lo que significa que se expanden a más industrias diferentes.

**Próximo paso** – Los responsables de políticas pueden usar este conocimiento para ayudar a las ciudades a crecer de manera inteligente. Las ciudades deben desarrollar nuevas industrias pero mantenerlas relacionadas para conservar el equilibrio. Esto ayuda a no dispersar los recursos y apoya una salud económica estable. También pueden compararse con ciudades de tamaño similar para fijar metas realistas.

**Resumen en una frase** – Durante casi dos siglos, las ciudades de EE.UU. han crecido y cambiado siguiendo un patrón estable que mantiene sus industrias conectadas y equilibradas.

articles.title: 27 things we wish we’d known when we started our PhDs
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 06 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03229-8Nature’s survey of PhD candidates reveals hard-won wisdom on choosing supervisors, managing mental health and surviving academic culture.
articles.content:
Nature’s 2025 PhD survey This article is the second in a series discussing the results of Nature’s 2025 PhD survey. The first looked at key findings of the survey. The survey, created in partnership with Thinks Insight & Strategy, a research consultancy based in London, launched in May and was advertised on nature.com, in Springer Nature digital products and through e-mail campaigns. It had 3,785 self-selecting respondents across 107 countries, with 44% describing themselves as female, 25% as belonging to an ethnic minority in their country of study and 33% as studying outside their country of origin. The full survey data sets are available at go.nature.com/4ncsuo1.

Starting a PhD can feel like stepping into uncharted territory. Although universities offer orientation programmes and supervisors provide research guidance, some of the most valuable lessons come from those who’ve walked the path before.

Nature’s 2025 PhD survey asked doctoral candidates worldwide what advice they would give to someone considering a similar degree (see ‘Recommendations to my pre-PhD self’). Many responses gave advice on what to consider when choosing a supervisor, research topic and laboratory, and the importance of scrutinizing personal motivations for doing a PhD. These quotes are taken from survey answers and have been anonymized, although they include the author’s gender, nationality, location and study year.

Find the right supervisor and lab

The people you work with matter as much as the project you choose.

“Choose your supervisor(s) very carefully. I’ve seen way too many students bullied, harassed and kicked out of the programme with their confidence in pieces.” — Female fourth-year student in South Africa

“When interviewing for a PhD slot, pay attention to how your prospective adviser treats others in the lab and the department. My lab ended up being really cliquey with certain individuals being excluded because my adviser plays favourites.” — Female fifth-year student in the United States

How money, politics and technology are redefining the PhD experience

“Do not go directly from an undergraduate degree to a PhD. Work for a year if possible in a job that will give you a better understanding of the problems you want to solve. That way your research can have the largest impact.” — Canadian female first-year student based in the United Kingdom

“The culture of the institution matters more than almost anything else. Listen to your gut when you feel like a university or lab culture is not a good fit.” — Female second-year student in the United States

“Take the opportunity, if it’s offered, to rotate through a few labs. You might be surprised by which lab you wind up feeling drawn to — I joined a lab that wasn’t initially on my radar.” — Female third-year student in the United States

Define your purpose

A PhD is a long commitment. Know your reasons for doing one and take steps to protect your well-being.

“Getting a PhD is a labour of love. Take the time to know that this is really what you want to pursue and if it is, then make sure you balance your mental health throughout the process. Burnout is much easier to avoid than to try to recover from.” — Female second-year student in the United States

Class of 2025: five PhD students reveal realigned priorities in wake of COVID and cuts

“Be vocal about what you want, nobody will stand up for you and give you what you want. Only you can focus on you, and that means getting a hold of what you want to progress your career.” — Indian female fifth-year student based in the United States

“Think about what you will do after your PhD from the very beginning. Create your own path with your own decisions, create your own burning torch for lighting your way. Because it can be a bit dark here.” — Female fourth-year student in Turkey

“Don’t let guilt run your PhD. Do your work during work hours and give yourself permission to disconnect afterward. Take your vacations without shame. No one finishes everything they plan.” — Female fifth-year student in Croatia

“If you feel like you’re not doing something you really love and truly believe in, abandon it. Trust your intuition. If you’re on the wrong train, it’s better to realize it as fast as possible.” — Female seventh-year student in Poland

Shape your project and skills

Choosing a topic is just the start. Your success depends on curiosity, persistence and building transferable skills along the way.

“Make sure you’re deeply interested in the process, not just the outcome. If you genuinely enjoy learning, problem-solving and digging deep into questions no one has fully answered before, that passion will carry you through the tough parts.” — Male second-year student in Brazil

11 reasons why we’ve stayed in academia

“Own your tasks … don’t get too bogged down with the details, but see how your research develops from a bigger picture perspective. Celebrate small wins: finishing an abstract for a conference, completing literature review for a specific objective and so forth.” — Kenyan male third-year student based in Germany

“Take every opportunity to learn how to write. Doing a PhD is an investment in your future, and the most transferable skill I have learnt is being able to communicate effectively through writing.” — Male fourth-year student in Canada

“Do not depend on AI tools to do the critical work of reading, understanding and writing. You need to analyse the results and not allow AI to do it as it might give biased outputs.” — Female fifth-year student in India

“Try to clearly define your personal workload limits. This will help you plan more effectively and avoid becoming overwhelmed by too many responsibilities or side projects.” — Female fourth-year student in Brazil

Clear the hurdles

Learn how to handle lab politics, heavy workloads and cultural or institutional obstacles.

“You will encounter more difficult challenges on this road than in your past student career, which might be in your academic work or, more likely, interpersonal relationships. The academic community is no more harmless or innocent than the outside world.” — Transgender male fifth-year student in Taiwan
articles.reasoning: The article shares valuable, broadly relevant insights from a large international survey of PhD candidates, offering practical advice on mental health, supervisor choice, and academic culture. This has a positive real-world impact by potentially improving PhD experiences and outcomes for many students worldwide. The scope is significant given the global and diverse respondent base, and the article provides substantial context and detailed advice, making it a meaningful resource.
articles.personality_title: PhD students share 27 key lessons to help others succeed
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Starting a PhD can be challenging and confusing. Many new students don’t know what to expect beyond basic university guidance. To understand these challenges better, Nature surveyed nearly 3,800 PhD candidates from 107 countries in 2025 to learn what advice they wish they had before starting.

**What happened** – The survey collected personal advice from PhD students about choosing supervisors, labs, and research topics, managing mental health, and navigating academic culture. Respondents shared their experiences anonymously, highlighting issues like the importance of a supportive supervisor, the value of understanding your own reasons for doing a PhD, and tips on balancing work and well-being.

**Impact** – This advice is important because it comes directly from people living the PhD experience worldwide. It helps future students avoid common problems such as bullying, poor lab environments, and burnout. For example, students stressed the need to choose supervisors carefully and to trust your feelings about the university’s culture. They also emphasized planning for life after the PhD and protecting mental health during the long journey.

**What’s next step** – The full survey data is publicly available for universities and students to use. This information can inspire better support systems and policies for PhD candidates. Future research may explore how these lessons impact PhD success and well-being over time.

**One-sentence takeaway** – PhD students worldwide offer honest, practical advice on choosing supervisors, managing mental health, and thriving in research to help others prepare for the journey ahead.
articles.personality_title_fr: 27 leçons clés partagées par des doctorants pour mieux réussir
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Commencer un doctorat peut être difficile et déroutant. Beaucoup de nouveaux étudiants ne savent pas à quoi s’attendre au-delà des conseils de base des universités. Pour mieux comprendre ces défis, Nature a interrogé près de 3 800 doctorants de 107 pays en 2025 pour savoir quels conseils ils auraient aimé recevoir avant de commencer.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – L’enquête a recueilli des conseils personnels de doctorants sur le choix des superviseurs, des laboratoires et des sujets de recherche, la gestion de la santé mentale et la navigation dans la culture académique. Les répondants ont partagé leurs expériences anonymement, mettant en lumière l’importance d’un superviseur soutenant, la valeur de comprendre ses propres motivations et des astuces pour équilibrer travail et bien-être.

**Impact** – Ces conseils sont importants car ils proviennent directement de personnes vivant l’expérience du doctorat dans le monde entier. Ils aident les futurs étudiants à éviter des problèmes courants comme le harcèlement, un mauvais environnement de laboratoire et l’épuisement. Par exemple, les étudiants insistent sur le choix attentif du superviseur et sur l’importance de faire confiance à son ressenti concernant la culture universitaire. Ils soulignent aussi la nécessité de planifier l’après-doctorat et de protéger sa santé mentale.

**Prochaine étape** – Les données complètes de l’enquête sont accessibles au public pour que les universités et les étudiants puissent en tirer parti. Ces informations peuvent encourager de meilleurs systèmes de soutien et des politiques adaptées aux doctorants. Des recherches futures pourraient étudier l’impact de ces conseils sur la réussite et le bien-être des doctorants.

**Une phrase clé** – Des doctorants du monde entier partagent des conseils honnêtes et pratiques sur le choix des superviseurs, la gestion de la santé mentale et la réussite en recherche pour mieux préparer les futurs candidats.

articles.title: Trajkov: The EU’s plan for growth in the Western Balkans will encourage shaping the future for the next generations
articles.summary: The ideas connect our people, making the region more integrated and stronger despite the challenges ahead, Trajkov said.
articles.content:
Skopje – The opportunities offered within the Growth Plan for the Western Balkans will encourage plans for shaping the future of the next generations, and therefore we must seize the chances we have and make dreams a reality in the name of a brighter future for all of us, said today the Deputy Minister for European Affairs Viktorija Trajkov in her address at the regional seminar organized by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) taking place in Skopje.

– We can accelerate the flow of goods in the region, we can strengthen our economies, and we can turn challenges into opportunities because we know how, Trajkov stated.

As announced by the Ministry of European Affairs, the Deputy Minister welcomed the participation of experts from all Western Balkan countries at the gathering and emphasized that the experiences from the United Nations and the European Union in this area are particularly significant and useful.

– As countries whose future aligns with European perspectives, we know our obligations and we know the path we need to build together and united. Ideas connect our people, making the region more integrated and stronger despite the challenges ahead. I firmly believe that the projects we are discussing today will create our future tomorrow, Trajkov emphasized. (October 3, 2025)
articles.reasoning: The article describes a regional growth plan for the Western Balkans aimed at economic integration and future development, which has broad positive implications for the region's population and future generations. It highlights cooperation, economic strengthening, and regional integration, which are meaningful for many people in the area. The article provides sufficient context about the plan's goals and significance.
articles.personality_title: Western Balkans growth plan aims to build a stronger, united future
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Western Balkans is a region in Southeast Europe with several countries working to improve their economies and connections. They face challenges but want to grow stronger together. The European Union (EU) and the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) support these efforts.

**What happened** – On October 3, 2025, Viktorija Trajkov, Deputy Minister for European Affairs in North Macedonia, spoke at a regional seminar in Skopje organized by UNECE. She talked about the EU’s Growth Plan for the Western Balkans, which aims to improve trade, strengthen economies, and create better opportunities for future generations. Experts from all Western Balkan countries joined the event to share ideas and experiences.

**Impact** – This plan is important because it helps countries in the region work closely together, making it easier to trade goods and grow their economies. By cooperating, these countries can turn problems into chances for progress. The plan also focuses on the future by supporting projects that will benefit young people and future generations in the Western Balkans.

**What’s next step** – The countries involved will continue working together to put the Growth Plan into action. They will use knowledge from the EU and the UN to improve their economies and connections. This teamwork aims to build a more united and stronger Western Balkans region over time.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU’s Growth Plan encourages Western Balkan countries to cooperate and build a stronger future for the next generations through economic growth and regional integration.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le plan de croissance pour les Balkans occidentaux vise un avenir plus fort et uni
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les Balkans occidentaux sont une région d’Europe du Sud-Est composée de plusieurs pays qui cherchent à améliorer leurs économies et leurs liens. Ils font face à des défis mais veulent devenir plus forts ensemble. L’Union européenne (UE) et la Commission économique des Nations unies pour l’Europe (CEE-ONU) soutiennent ces efforts.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 3 octobre 2025, Viktorija Trajkov, vice-ministre aux Affaires européennes en Macédoine du Nord, a pris la parole lors d’un séminaire régional organisé à Skopje par la CEE-ONU. Elle a présenté le Plan de croissance de l’UE pour les Balkans occidentaux, qui vise à améliorer le commerce, renforcer les économies et créer de meilleures opportunités pour les générations futures. Des experts de tous les pays des Balkans occidentaux ont participé pour partager leurs idées et expériences.

**Impact** – Ce plan est important car il aide les pays de la région à travailler étroitement ensemble, facilitant ainsi le commerce et la croissance économique. En coopérant, ces pays peuvent transformer les problèmes en opportunités. Le plan met aussi l’accent sur l’avenir en soutenant des projets qui profiteront aux jeunes et aux générations à venir dans les Balkans occidentaux.

**Prochaine étape** – Les pays concernés vont continuer à collaborer pour mettre en œuvre le Plan de croissance. Ils utiliseront les connaissances de l’UE et de l’ONU pour améliorer leurs économies et leurs liens. Ce travail d’équipe vise à construire une région des Balkans occidentaux plus unie et plus forte avec le temps.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le Plan de croissance de l’UE encourage les pays des Balkans occidentaux à coopérer et à construire un avenir plus fort pour les prochaines générations grâce à la croissance économique et à l’intégration régionale.
articles.personality_title_es: El plan de crecimiento para los Balcanes Occidentales busca un futuro más fuerte y unido
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los Balcanes Occidentales son una región del sureste de Europa formada por varios países que quieren mejorar sus economías y conexiones. Enfrentan desafíos, pero desean fortalecerse juntos. La Unión Europea (UE) y la Comisión Económica para Europa de las Naciones Unidas (CEPE-ONU) apoyan estos esfuerzos.

**Qué pasó** – El 3 de octubre de 2025, Viktorija Trajkov, subsecretaria de Asuntos Europeos de Macedonia del Norte, habló en un seminario regional en Skopje organizado por la CEPE-ONU. Habló sobre el Plan de Crecimiento de la UE para los Balcanes Occidentales, que busca mejorar el comercio, fortalecer las economías y crear mejores oportunidades para las próximas generaciones. Expertos de todos los países de la región participaron para compartir ideas y experiencias.

**Impacto** – Este plan es importante porque ayuda a los países a trabajar juntos, facilitando el comercio y el crecimiento económico. Al cooperar, pueden convertir los problemas en oportunidades. Además, el plan se enfoca en el futuro apoyando proyectos que beneficiarán a los jóvenes y a las próximas generaciones en los Balcanes Occidentales.

**Próximo paso** – Los países seguirán colaborando para implementar el Plan de Crecimiento. Usarán los conocimientos de la UE y la ONU para mejorar sus economías y conexiones. Este trabajo en equipo busca construir una región de los Balcanes Occidentales más unida y fuerte con el tiempo.

**Frase clave** – El Plan de Crecimiento de la UE impulsa a los países de los Balcanes Occidentales a cooperar y construir un futuro más fuerte para las próximas generaciones mediante el crecimiento económico y la integración regional.
